answers.text:
Hi Anita, 
Thank you for your question.  Here are some helpful resources regarding art programs for local government.  
The Knowledge Network published a document relating to expansion practices for reaching new audiences in the arts.  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/303917/Report_Showcases_Cultural_Strategies
I've also found some great resources relating specifically to California cities that Louise mentioned.  
Sacramento's Art in Public Places program invites artists in the Northern California area to participate. 
http://www.sacmetroarts.org/art-in-public-places.html
Alameda Count Arts Commission is committed to public art expenditure.
http://www.acgov.org/arts/html/public_art.html
The Department of Urban Studies and Planning at San Francisco State University published a great report on Public Art in Berkeley.
http://www.cityofberkeley.info/uploadedFiles/Planning_and_Development/Level_3_-_DAP/4d-PublicArt-Attach3-SFSUstudy%20.pdf
Here is San Francisco's Public Art Ordinance.
http://www.sfartscommission.org/pubartcollection/documents/pa00-public-art-ordinance/
San Diego's Commission for Arts and Culture also published their ordinance requirements for their city. 
http://www.ncarts.org/SmART%20Initiative/Tools%20and%20Components/Public%20Art/Public%20Art%20in%20Private%20Development/San%20Diego-CA.pdf
Pasadena's Public Art Program website gives access to their guidelines for development.
http://cityofpasadena.net/arts/Public_Art_Program/
Don't forget to check back to the Arts and Culture Knowledge Network topic page for more updates! 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/13/Arts_and_Culture
I hope this helps to answer your question!  Let us know if we can help you find any more information or resources. 
Hilary Badger
Knowledge Network, Intern
ICMA
